quote.para: The committee has some major reservations about this evidence. Those opposing the changes were able to provide considerably more detail about the cost of products across a broader spectrum of items than was the ACCC.

speech.para: Other criticisms of the ACCC's methodology raised in the inquiry and noted by the government senators included the fact that the ACCC did not take into account factors such as freight costs, conversion costs and discounts. Committee members observed that the survey was restricted and that its weightings were `unusual'.

In response to the ACCC report, the software industry produced its own evidence which showed that the alleged huge price differences did not in fact exist. In their submission to the Senate inquiry, the Business Software Alliance of Australia demonstrated that PC software prices in Australia are on average 22 per cent less than similar products in the United Kingdom, slightly less than those in New Zealand and only marginally more than those available in the US. Looking at computer games, an important and growing subsector of the digital content sector, an Access Economics study referred to by the Australian Visual Software Distributors Association demonstrated that 97 per cent of all computer game sales in 1998 showed that prices in the UK were 32 per cent higher than Australian prices and that US prices were only seven per cent cheaper. More recent evidence tendered by the Interactive Entertainment Association of Australia on 2 August 2002 indicates that these comparisons relating to computer games still hold true.

So it is fairly clearâand even the government senators involved in the inquiry into parallel importation seemed to be swayed by this evidenceâthat this big bogeyman of higher software prices in Australia is nothing more than a fantasy to which the coalition has subscribed. So the answer to the first questionâwhether we are currently paying too muchâis an emphatic no. So, if there is no problem to begin with, the next question that must be asked is: will parallel importation reduce prices? The answer to this question is: probably not. There is no evidence to suggest that it will and plenty of evidence to say that it probably will not. Once again I quote the report of the Senate inquiry:

quote.para: Evidence provided by the music industry demonstrated that there are no consistently lower prices available for top selling CDs, and no evidence was provided to demonstrate that consumers of items other than popular music obtained any benefits at all from parallel importation.

speech.para: I remind the Senate that these were government senators making these observations. This inconsistency within the government only gets worse. In the case of software, it makes sense that prices will not be reduced, certainly at the top end of the market. Given that Australia's prices are relatively low, the industry points out that it would not be a commercially viable proposition to import the latest software at even lower prices into Australia. Of course, the viability may well be there if the software is pirated or if the software is dumped in Australia from undersold product or remainder stock from foreign markets. The software equivalents to `back-catalogue' CDs are older versions, not just old products. In other words, the only effect will be unmarketable leftovers of older versions of software products. This would include older products that may not work on newer operating systems or are no longer provided with technical support by vendors, a crucial element of software on sale, and Australian software firms will bear the blame and loss of reputation because of this impact. Indeed, I noted a story in the Australian in which the PC Internet Professionals Association was quoted as saying:

quote.para: ... you might get warehouses with thousands of educational games that are end of model run outs from America ...

speech.para: Meanwhile, the worthwhile softwareâthe new products and the latest versions keeping up with the latest hardwareâwill be unchanged. So the legislation put before us is basically pointless in this regard: it offers an ineffectual solution for a non-existent problem.

However, it is not so ephemeral on Australia's software and digital content industry. There is a fear that the effect of this bill will be quite negative. Australia's software and digital content industryâin particular our computer games industryâis a young, vibrant and competitive sector, one that has the potential to increase Australia's proportion of the massive global computer games market. We should be encouraging this. Unfortunately, the reality is that this government has barely thrown a bone to the sector. All of the hard work in encouraging this industry to take root in Australia has been done, in fact, by the state governments. I acknowledge in particular the work of the Victorian Labor government in promoting and supporting the computer games industry sector. I note that as recently as December last year the minister for information technology was waxing lyrical about the computer games industry, saying that the government supported it. On that point, I can see no tangible policies that give effect to that sentiment.

According to the Games Development Association of Australia, to give some of the credentials of this emerging and growing sector, the interactive computer games industry exported an estimated $60 million worth of products in 2001 and approximately $100 million worth of exports in 2002. It employs around 650 full-time artists, designers and producers in approximately 40 companies. Industry estimates predict that employment within the Australian games industry could reach 1,500 within five years as Australian developers win more of the estimated $20 billion spent globally each year on computer games.

This is the second piece of legislation that affects the computer games industry directly. The first related to classification, and this is another issue that has been raised by the industry in relation to this bill. Australia is one of the few countries that mandates a classification regime for computer games. To avoid being refused classification and/or banned in Australia, there are several games that have been modified to meet the appropriate classification levels. However, these modifications are on the CD or DVD itself, and often the packaged product looks exactly the same. So, under parallel importation, software could come into Australia as inappropriately classified or even as a version which would otherwise be prohibited, and consumersâ parents, children and whoeverâwill be none the wiser. When this happens, who will be blamed? It will be the software and computer games companies. They may be vulnerable to breaches of the classification regime, despite the fact that the legislation, if this bill is passed, will dictate that they are denied control to manage the classification of their games in the Australian market.

Now we come to the issue of intellectual property and copyright. The software and games industry have argued that parallel importation will increase the risk of importation of pirated material and that the pirated imports will undermine their market share. It is a fair point and we would expect the industry to say that. However, this raises the very big, vexed and controversial question of the copyright policies pursued particularly by global software and games companies, who are renowned for quite mercilessly pursuing stricter and stricter regimes to protect their market share around the worldâoften, it is argued, at the expense of diversity of products in the market or, as in the unproven view of the ACCC, at the expense of downward pressure on price. So without excusing the behaviour of these companies, I cannot blame the software development and digital content industry here in Australia for being concerned about their future.

The government has been inconsistent and even contradictory in its approach to intellectual property, and I think these confused messages are adding to the concern being expressed by many subsectors of the ICT sector, particularly the software and digital content producers. On the one hand, the government has given the industry every reason to believe that it is full on, strong and cares about protection of copyright in the software and digital copyright industries. For example, if you read the recent report of the Broadband Advisory Group, which the minister chaired, the government said on page 36, section 6.2:

quote.para: Market and technical uncertainties surrounding the management of digital rights are inhibiting content owners from making rich content available to broadband networks.

speech.para: The government is acknowledging the important role of digital rights and copyright protection for small business ventures in trying to put policies in place to stimulate a nascent industry. This is in fact the very issue that the Australian software and games sector has used as an argument against this bill. The government is contradicting its own view through the pursuance of this bill in the chamber. To further demonstrate the inconsistent approach by the government, the next section of the report advocates, in fact, a looser regime for the management of public sector IP. The government has a different view about how to manage IP having regard to whether it is the public or the private sector. In section 6.3 of the same report under the section titled `Access to Government Intellectual Property', it states:

quote.para: A more flexible approach for Government produced content designed for broadband platforms could provide greater incentives for repurposing the content for other users. For example, the Commonwealth would generally assert ownership of copyright on works that it funded, such as a piece of online education material. A more flexible approach may enable the developers of this material to repurpose it for overseas markets in addition to its original intent.

speech.para: These are all very worthy sentiments contained in this report and they are aimed at inspiring the local software and digital content industries. But, again, my point is that the government is contradicting itself and sending out multiple messages to the sector about IP. Depending on who the coalition are talking to, sometimes they identify IP and strong IP protection as an absolutely necessary element to push forward industry development and sometimesâlike we are seeing with this billâthey completely disregard those concerns and put forward a proposition of parallel importation that moves in the opposite direction. The industry has argued that that will have the direct effect of stifling growth and expansion of the industry. It is no wonder that people are confused.

Another twist is that the government has not even bothered to address recommendations made in the Cracking down on copycats reportâand of course that does not include some of the amendments that we are discussing today. But as my colleague Senator Ludwig said earlier, this response is certainly very weak. The lack of response by the government to those overarching recommendations about piracy apparently is because it has been stalled in the office of the very same minister who is saying all of these great things about how tight IP control should beâthat minister being Senator Alston. You can see we have a minister who must be just about writhing on the floor after endless policy twists in relation to IP.

The coalition does not know how to be consistent, because I do not believe they have thought it through. We are witnessing a government that is happy to legislate on the run, reacting to issues around IP, as they arise, with little clue about leadership, consistency and direction. It seems that it is the view of the latest interestâwhoever was making representations to the minister most recentlyâthat is presented in the government's legislative agenda or indeed its latest report. It is all over the place and I think that is very unfortunate. I hate to think what is going to happen with the Framework for the Future document, which I spoke about in this chamber the other evening, and what it is going to say about IP management. I will be looking for consistencyâor, indeed, a continuation of this government's record of inconsistency, which is I am sure what will be expressed.

It is clear to me that the local software and digital content industry is as good as any in the world, but I am concerned that this policy confusion will scare off investors who are happy to shop around jurisdictions for a country they perceive to be the most favourable in policy terms for domiciling games and other software production. My concern is that these investors will view Australia as a country that, at best, has inconsistent policies on IP management of software and digital content and, at worst, does not do anything to support the growth of software development.

This bill places a black mark on Australia's credentials as a place for investment by investors who make games and other software development possible. You can add to that the Luddite image of the minister responsible and his disparaging attitude over time to the games industry as a driver of broadband, and some negligence, I think, in promoting broadband, which is a key element in the promotion of the software and digital content sectors. Who can forget his notorious comments that the only reason people want broadband is because they want to play games on it, citing South Korea as an example, and asking why Australia should bother installing and investing in broadband networks. I believe Australia's software industry has a huge future but, at this stage, it should not be left on the hillside to fend for itself, like a Spartan baby. For these reasons, I am sorry that the Democrats have decided to support this aspect of the bill. Clearly, it will offer no legitimate benefit to consumers and it will create a great deal of IP uncertainty around a tremendous Australian industry.

talk.start.para: âI seek leave to have my speech in the second reading debate on the Copyright Amendment (Parallel Importation) Bill 2002 incorporated in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.
I rise today to speak to the Copyright Amendment (Parallel Importation) Bill. In doing so I wish to raise with the Senate a number of serious concerns I have with this piece of legislation.
The particular Bill in front of us today represents nothing more than this government's blind obsession with fulfilling its ideological agenda.

The first example of this is an obvious one and that is a desire to deregulate any and every industry it can. The second is to remove any protection afforded to Australian intellectual culture and to the country's artists who enrich it.

For most Australians, culture means so much more than cricket and football. Australians are large consumers of intellectual and artistic works and most believe them to be worthy of Government protection.
In light of this, the question has to be askedâ
Why is the Government pursuing this legislation?
Is there evidence to suggest that competition in the industries the bill targets is either poor or non-existent and in need of a decent shake-up?
Well, this is precisely the viewpoint the Government would like to have us believe, and it is intent on trying to prove it, no matter how distorted facts and figures need to be to do so.

The Bill before the Senate proposes to amend the Copyright Act of 1968 to enable the legal parallel importation and subsequent commercial distribution of books; computer software products, including interactive computer games; periodical publications (such as journals and magazines); and sheet music.
Legal parallel importation was first introduced in to Australia in 1991 by the passage of the Keating Labor Government's Copyright Amendment Bill 1990.

The intention of the Bill was to allow the commercial importation, without infringement of an owner's copyright, of non-pirate copies of books first published overseas, non-pirate copies of books published in Australia or overseas where they could not be supplied within 90 days of an order being placed and non-pirate copies of books intended for private use.
In addition, the Bill provided that the copyright in a foreign book would be retained if the book was published in Australia within 30 days of its first publication abroad.

The result of the subsequent law saw the ensured availability of a wide range of titles and a competitive industry, but at the same time a protected Australian industry and also protected Australian jobs.

The Keating Government's Copyright amendment ensured that Australians would have access to a global media market, but at the same time, the provisions of the bill protected and encouraged Australian businesses to provide Australians access to it.

Under the current regime, local businesses have 30 or 90 days (in most circumstances) to provide Australian consumers with access to a particular title before that opportunity is granted to foreign interests.

In 1998, the current federal government amended the Copyright Act so as to allow for the legal parallel importation and sale of legitimate copies of sound recordings, namely CDs, with no 30 or 90-day rules attached.

In considering the current proposal before us today, which aims to extend a similar regime across a number of other industries, it is important that we look at the outcomes experienced by both consumers and the Australian industry involved following the 1998 decision and subsequent law.

Unfortunately, the first thing to note in this regard, is that no official government-sponsored inquiry of any depth or substance has been held in to the Australian sound recording industry to analyse the changes made by the 1998 decision.

An inquiry of this sort would have been of great benefit when considering this amendment and unfortunately without it we are left with no basis to compare the alleged benefits supposedly inevitable with the passage of this bill with any actual outcomes experienced so far.
Without a proper inquiry and evidence, we are left with only hearsay on which to base our judgements.
To this end, and with little tested evidence, widespread opinion would have it that parallel importation of CDs has not led to substantially lower prices for consumers as promised or greater variety.
Rather the practice is widely recognised to have led to a massive increase in piracy and therefore to an attack on the legitimate entitlements of the Australian music industry.
Moreover, it has led to diminished investment in Australian music artistry.

Piracy is a practice that undermines the global media industry. Its effects are certainly not limited to the music industry. In deed, it is probably the number one issue affecting publishing and multimedia distribution industries of all sorts around the world as well as affecting the rights and incomes of artists and copyright owners.
Piracy is costing and undermining publishers, it is costing and undermining the work of authors and artists, it costs jobs and it is also costing consumers heavily.

Invariably, costs associated with a company's loss of income to piracy are recouped through industrial downsizing, a curb on innovation and also through consumers being charged higher prices for outputs at the checkout.
Piracy is âcompetitionsâ biggest enemy and the enemy of lower priced goods for consumers.

Numerous machines with the ability to recreate music and computer software products to perfection or close-to have been commercially available at reasonably low cost to the consumer for some time. With the ever-improving nature of the technology, these machines will become easier and cheaper to buy and use, they will be technologically better equipped, and will therefore become a problem of greater and greater magnitude in to the future.

The ease with which imitation outputs have been being produced and will continue to be created and distributed throughout society is remarkable. Costs to the industries usurped by pirated material are enormous.

A 1999 study by the Business Software Association of Australia revealed that Australian distributors and retailers lose $269 million per year through piracy alone and that a drop in piracy to the US level would mean the creation of 7,000 additional jobs and add $1 billion to the Australian economy.

A lack of policing of multimedia industries is certainly another factor contributing to the rise of piracy. It is an area of policing that the Government needs to improve upon, regardless of the outcome of this particular bill, in order to protect the integrity of copyright law and all laws governing production and distribution and to also protect the rights of those in our community that endeavour to make a living out of cultural production.
In 2001, the Senate referred this particular Bill to the Senate's Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee.
I must note that I have some serious concerns with the manner in which the Senate Inquiry around this Bill was undertaken.

Three public hearings were held in Melbourne and Sydney and many of the individuals and organisations that appeared before the committee noted that they had to keep their comments brief because of the tight time they had been allotted before the Committee.

Contrast this with the previous inquiry into parallel importation for music CDs that was referred to the Committee on 2nd December 1997 for an inquiry and report by 1st April 1998. This inquiry into only the music industry, held seven public hearings in three cities, Sydney, Melbourne and Perth.
It is far from satisfactory that such an important inquiry into such sizeable changes of these important and convoluted industries could be conducted so quickly.
It is totally inadequate to expect members of the Senate to vote to make such significant changes to these industries with such little consideration.

It's granted that these changes have been mooted for some time now, but with a lack of real critical analysis of it is simply unreasonable to vote to implement them with a slim hope that benefits could follow.
In it's report to the Senate, the Government controlled Committee noted that there was possibly too much dependence on the ACCC for data.
But of serious concern is the fact that the ACCC's data was challenged by other submissions and organisations involved with the committee and found to be flawed.
Sample data was either very old, too narrow, averaged over too long a period of time or gathered from unreliable sources, as just some of the concerns.

In light of this it is of even more concern that the Government itself has been so heavily reliant upon the data provided by the ACCC as the basis to its argument for the need for this legislative change. This reliance is demonstrated quite clearly by the use of the ACCC's evidence in the Explanatory Memorandum to justify acceptance or rejection of various options.
Doubling up on this flawed data is also another problem noted by the Committee, particularly with respect to it being used in the Explanatory Memorandum.
Reference is made, for example, to the fact thatâ
âThe Prices Surveillance Authority and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission have both recommended this course of action as the only means to ensure genuine competitionâ.
The Prices Surveillance Authority report referred to was undertaken in 1992.

It must be noted that the ACCC was formed in 1995 with the merger of the Prices Surveillance Authority and the Trade Practices Commission, which were both previously chaired by Professor Fels, who is now the Chairman of the ACCC.
The Government's Explanatory Memorandum attached to this bill suggests in no uncertain terms that the two bodies, with supposedly no connection or common thread have come to the very same conclusion.
This kind of misleading statement is something we have become accustomed to from this Government.
Trickery, it seems, is its forte.
While that might be, I find it a very sad state of affairs.

Apart from the Australian Consumers' Association, which was heavily dependent upon data from the ACCC to form its support for the bill before us today, the remaining organisation that indicated support for the proposed amendments was the National Machine Operators Association, who declared to the Senate Committee that it based its decision to support the current Bill almost solely on the research conducted by the ACCC as well.
The three organisations supporting the bill all substantially relied on out of date and potentially flawed ACCC data.
The Australian Visual Software Developers Association and the Business Software Association of Australia solidly dispute the ACCC's assertions made to the Senate Committee.
AVSDA provided evidence of an Access Economics report that showed that in 1998, prices for games software were 32% higher in the UK than in Australia and only 7% lower than in the US.

AVSDA also questioned the validity of the ACCC report that stated that computer games were, quote `on average 33 per cent higher than in the US', unquote, based on a comparison of 9 titles. The Access Economics report stated that the ACCC's comparison is âbadly flawed and should not be relied uponâ.

The BSAA commissioned its own software prices survey which tracked every advertised price of more than 60 leading software programs from nine vendors over a two month period from October 2000 to December 2000.
The Pricing Survey found that business PC software prices in Australia are, on average, 22 per cent lower than the same products in the UK and 2 per cent lower than in New Zealand.
It found that Australian prices were 3.54 per cent higher than average prices in the USA, but this did not include USA State sales tax where this applies.

Although some differentials were found, these often related to programs where there were adaptations or modifications necessary to customise them for the Australian market, such as Computer Aided Design Software.

On average however, across a wide range of leading products, Australian software is priced lower than in comparable markets, and is on par with the USA, a market that does not have to bear export costs.
Mr John Stonier, the dissenting member of the Government's Intellectual Property and Competition Review Committee, which submitted its final report on 30 September 2000, concluded:

âIt is not clear that parallel import provisions restrict the competitive process, or that the costs of such restrictions exceed the benefits. It is also not clear that there are alternative cost-effective means of achieving the same goals.
âThis conclusion is particularly true for the book industry in Australia.
âThere are over 250 publishers employing more than 4000 people.
âIn 1997-98 they sold more than 110 million books, of which 60 per cent were Australian and published nearly 7000 new Australian titles.
âSales exceeded $1000 million, of which more than $100 million were exported, mainly to the United States ($40 million), New Zealand ($25 million) and the United Kingdom ($17 million)â.

According to Mr Stonier, âthese figures are consistent with Australia having a thriving and competitive industry. They are also consistent with the view that parallel imports are not impeding or restraining the competitive processâ.

The Text Publishing Company submitted that the 30-day rule has created an impetus for publishers to price their books competitively relative to overseas prices because it allows for the constant, daily possibility of the market opening.

The Text Publishing Company asserted that the 30-day rule has caused the market to behave as though it were already open while at the same time providing traditional territorial copyright to Australian publishers.
Additionally, the Australian Publishers' Association also supports the current 30-day and 90-day legislation.

The organisation supported it at its introduction in 1991 because it reinforced territorial copyright, which it believes underpins investment in copyright material and investment in publishing in the country.

This was the intention of the Keating Government's 1990 Copyright amendment bill and it has delivered the intended results. It sought availability of titles and competition, but a protected competition that encouraged local investment rather than a dog-eat-dog industry where little benefits would be passed on to the wider community.
A number of organisations told the Committee that the removal of the current parallel importation restrictions would result in the decline of Australia's publishing printing industries.

The Printing Industries Association of Australia stated that in discussions it had had with major Australian book printers, it assessed, that with the passage of this Bill the Australian book production industry would lose in the order of $35 million and also the loss of around $13 million in the paper production industry.

The PIAA estimates that the impact of these losses would be largely felt in regional areas of Australia, most notably, in Maryborough in my state of Victoria, in Adelaide and in parts of Tasmania where paper is currently produced.
Australian publishing does not operate in a global market the way music does.
Australia is one of four major English language publishers alongside the UK, the US, and Canadaâall of whom protect territorial copyright.

The Australian Society of Authors put it to the Senate Committee that no other jurisdiction with a market of significance other than Australia intends to make the same changes contained in this bill in relation to parallel importing for their book industries.

International governments like those in the US and UK understand the need to nurture and protect their local cultural industries and as such they are committed to import restriction arrangements and they also show no sign of liberalising their own industries.

In light of the protection afforded to these industries by governments such as the US and UK, the Australian government's decision to open our industries up to international competition is simply unnecessary, is out of step, and shows complete disregard for the artists and businesses striving to make a living out of these industries in Australia.

We in the Labor Party are extremely concerned that there has been no consideration whatsoever of the impact the successful passage of this Bill would have on Australian authors, Australian cultural identity and the choices Australian consumers will have, if unrestricted parallel importation is introduced into the Australian book industry.
The Australian Society of Authors (ASA) argued that the Bill would lead to the dumping in Australia of surplus books from overseas and to lower or removed royalties from them to Australian authors.
The ASA said there would be little incentive for local publishers to promote Australian authors when their investment could be undermined by imports dumped from overseas.

The ASA stated that if territorial copyright was abolished then Australian authors would have no choice but to sell their property to publishers overseas and then have their work imported back into Australia.

The Australian Publishers' Association accepts that the price of some titles would reduce without parallel importation restrictions, however these would be notably imports of titles that are remainders, overstocks and overruns in overseas territories. It argued to the Senate Committee that this âadvantageâ to consumers does not outweigh the cost to the local industry.

In accordance with the inter-governmental Competition Principles Agreement, legislation that restricts competition should only be retained where it can be demonstrated that the benefits of the restriction to the community as a whole exceed the costs, and the objective of the legislation can only be achieved by restricting competition.
In my opinion, the multimedia industry is a prime example of the need to restrict total competition in order to gain better outcomes for the Australian community as a whole.

As former Senator Cooney noted in his additional comments to Labor's dissenting report from the Legal and Constitutional Committee, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is an institution essential to the welfare of the Nation. But its functions do not include the guardianship of the people's cultural, social or spiritual life. Parliament must ensure that in performing its vital task on their behalf the Commission does not prejudice their soul and spirit. Accordingly parliament should not pass this legislation in its present form.

At the end of the day, much of the evidence in support of the Bill provided to the Senate Committee was inconclusive. In fact much of the evidence was highly questionable at best, or at worst was a blatant distortion of reality. It certainly has failed to prove to me, the serious need for passing this legislation.
The four organisations and three submissions supporting the Bill's passage, among the 13 advocating the Bill's rejection, relied on flawed ACCC research to come to those conclusions.

The Government is intent on trying to prove that these industries are anti-competitive, however its evidence in support of this, when tested against real intellectual scrutiny and inquiry, simply don't add up.

What is needed to help drive down prices on consumers is a more focussed attempt to wipe out piracy. Government commitment to this end would lift a huge economic burden on businesses and would enable them to concentrate spending on innovation, investment and jobs and at the same time drive down already competitive prices on outputs.
This Bill is a poor attempt to deal with the printing, publishing and software industries and as such it should be rejected.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: âMy question is directed to Senator Hill, the Minister for Defence and Minister representing the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the minister aware of media reports concerning contracts for the postwar reconstruction of Iraq going overwhelmingly to United States firms? Is the minister also aware that British politicians and engineering and construction firms have complained about being excluded from bidding for USAID-funded contracts? Can the minister confirm that no Australian companies have yet been allowed to bid for, nor been engaged for, any USAID contracts in Iraq? What is the Howard government's attitude to the exclusion of Australian firms from participating in the multimillion dollar contracts that the US government has already let for reconstruction in Iraq?

âI am not aware of any Australian firms obtaining contracts with the US government. As I understand it, if it is being funded through American government aid then foreign companies are excluded. But I would like to check on that. In relation to Australian companies participating in the reconstruction of Iraq, I hope they will do so. Obviously, as I said yesterday, Australia will want to play a part in the reconstruction of Iraq, and Australia does have a good performance record in relation to a number of the sectors that will be in particular demand in the task of reconstructing Iraq. If I think particularly of the agricultural sector, dryland farming is an area of expertise of the Australian agricultural community and I am sure that Australia has significant expertise that could be brought to bear in that sector, to the benefit primarily of the Iraqi people and perhaps with some incidental benefit to the Australian suppliers. In relation to contracts under American aid as opposed to Australian aid, obviously Australian firms are bound by US law.

âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, in light of the very serious concerns raised today by the Australian Industry Group and the Chamber of Commerce and Industry about the exclusion of Australian firms from an open and competitive tender process for these important contracts, how does the Howard government respond to reports of contracts the Bush administration has awarded overnight to a subsidiary of Halliburton Corporation? Is the Howard government concerned about the precedent set by this substantial contract to a company closely and controversially linked to US Vice-President Cheney? Are Australian companies justified in seeing this contract to a US corporation on the inside track with the Bush administration as just the beginning of cronyism and nationalistic favouritism?

âI do not think the honourable senator listened to the answer that I gave. If under US law contracts that are paid for through US government aid have to be given to US companies, then, obviously, an Australian company is not going to have that opportunity. That does not mean that there will not be a whole range of other economic opportunities associated with the primary task of reconstructing and rebuilding Iraq. In relation to Halliburton, it is a highly-regarded international company and is highly respected. I would presume that, if it has been successful in some US government contract, it is pursuant to the tendering processes that are appropriate.

âMy question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator the Hon. Robert Hill, and I ask: will the minister update the Senate on the role that Australia's Defence Force is playing in the international effort to disarm Iraq?

âI am pleased to report again on that subject, and in particular to report that all Australian personnel in the Middle East are safe and well and that coalition operations to disarm Iraq remain on track. Australian special forces continue their strategic reconnaissance operations deep within Iraq. Our FA18s continue to fly defensive counter air patrols without incident, although some missions were not conducted because of the appalling weather. The weather has also disrupted the activities of the Navy clearance divers, but we anticipate that the crucial port of Umm Qasr will be open to humanitarian supplies very soon. Our Navy is playing a critical role in ensuring the safety of the vessels that will shortly begin providing humanitarian relief, including 100,000 tonnes of Australian wheat, to the Iraqi people. Our C130 and P3 reconnaissance aircraft and other force elements continue with their important tasks.

answer.para: Overall we remain satisfied with the progress of the coalition campaign. The government and our coalition partners have emphasised that we never expected the disarmament of Iraq to be accomplished easily or without cost. Unfortunately, poor weather, some friendly and civilian casualties and occasional tactical setbacks are part and parcel of war. Tragically, many of these seems to have resulted from Iraqi practices inconsistent with the laws of armed conflict, including location of military assets close to civilians, feigned surrenders and the use of paramilitary in civilian dress to attack Iraqi civilians and coalition forces. But, of course, such behaviour from this regime should come as no surprise. It does not, however, threaten the success of the campaign; it merely strengthens our resolve.

The outlook on the ground is positive. In the south, coalition forces continue to consolidate their hold in Umm Qasr and around the key city of Basra. The coalition have also made significant gains in stabilising the situation in the west and north. Humanitarian supplies are already flowing into Iraq. Coalition forces are nearing Baghdad, having moved over 300 kilometres in fewer than five days. The advice we have is that the poor weather has enabled our forces to consolidate their positions and communications and to make any necessary adjustments in preparation for the move against Baghdad. Republican Guard units outside Baghdad are under heavy and sustained air attack, despite the poor weather. According to the Chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff, General Myers, coalition aircraft flew nearly 1,000 sorties over Iraq on 24 March, most of them against Republican Guard forces.

Our forces have encountered Iraqi soldiers who are deserting and only want to return home. When we have encountered such soldiers, we have allowed them to do so. Despite the heavy damage inflicted on the Iraqi military, we should be in no doubt that the campaign is entering a new, more difficult and dangerous phase. I know that the thoughts of all Australians are with our forces as they see this difficult but vital task through and uphold the proud tradition of the Australian Defence Force.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Hill, Minister for Defence. Can the minister confirm that many Australian Defence Force personnel have already been in the gulf for almost two months? Given predictions from many analysts that the conflict could run for six to eight weeks, can the government now confirm that troops are being prepared to rotate into the gulf to relieve existing forces? The minister stated this week in question time that Australia's role in any peacekeeping force after the war is yet to be decided. When will this decision be taken, and why is there a delay? Finally, will troops already deployed potentially take part in any peacekeeping role, or would other troops be deployed for this task?

âThere are a number of subquestions in that question. We have had forces in the gulf region for the best part of the last 12 years, in particular on the Navy ships that have been part of the multilateral interception force. We announced when forces were sent to the gulf region as part of the predeployment for Operation Bastille. Australian forces were not in Iraq until after the Prime Minister announced that they were under operational command early last week.

answer.para: I have answered the question about rotation on the last two days. With the possible exception of the ships, we are not anticipating a need for rotation of forces, but that will obviously be reassessed a little further down the line. We are not anticipating a growth in the number of force personnel we have in the region, nor a change in the make-up of that force. Will they be engaged in subsequent peacekeeping activities? That is obviously yet to be determined, although the Prime Minister has indicated, and I said in the Senate the day before yesterday, that we do not intend to be part of any broadscale defence operation by a peacekeeping force. We may fill capability niches to meet a UN or other coalition peacekeeping requirement if we determine that it is in Australia's national interest to do so.

talk.start.para: âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Are there sufficient FA18 pilots left in Australia to replace all those deployed should they need to be relieved? Given the tempo of our air operations, what is the expected length of their deployment?

âAs I understand it, we have three operational squadrons of FA18s and we have sent one to the gulf. We have not announced the period we anticipate for the pilots' deployment, and it is not our intention to do so at the moment. It is possible, although unlikely, that they may need to be rotated. If so, there are sufficient pilots to allow for such a rotation.

âMy question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. How are information and communications technologies, including technologies that have been developed in Australia, helping both to protect Australia's troops in the Iraq conflict and to minimise the number of civilian casualties?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI thank Senator Santoro for a question with a very high degree of relevance at the present time. There is no doubt that advanced technologies have revolutionised military conflict, ever since the Gulf War in 1991. No-one welcomes military conflict at any time. However, in the case of the current action in Iraq, such conflict is necessary to ensure that Saddam Hussein's weapons of mass destruction are eradicated.

answer.para: It is worth noting that a number of highly advanced Australian manufactured or developed technologies are playing a significant role in the current military conflict. These technologies demonstrate the capabilities and the efficiency of Australia's defence industries, as well as the close links between defence and information and communications technologies. For example, HMAS Anzac is playing a key role in the conflict by engaging a number of enemy targets, including enemy bunkers, artillery positions and coastal defensive positions. HMAS Anzac was manufactured in Australia by Transfield and Tenix. Its main armament is a forward-mounted five-inch gun that utilises ammunition manufactured by Australian Defence Industries and is controlled by combat system software developed by Saab Systems. Reports indicate that, using this system, all targets have been successfully engaged. The effectiveness of this weaponry system has earned the praise of British commandos.

The Nulka active missile decoy system is playing an important role in the gulf in ensuring the safety of Australia's service men and women. The Nulka is a world-leading missile defence system that is highly effective in decoying anti-ship missiles. The Nulka propulsive unit and its launchers and fire control systems were all manufactured by BAE Systems Australia, while ADI Mulwala assembled the units. The original Nulka system was developed by DSTO and that led to a co-development by the US and Australian industries, with BAE as the current Australian partner. As senators know, the safety of the deep port of Umm Qasr is crucial in ensuring access for the humanitarian effort to assist the Iraqi population. De-mining of the port is a potentially critical part of securing Umm Qasr, and Australia's troops have the capacity to assist in this work. This involves highly dangerous underwater diving. Part of the equipment that can be used in this work is a diver recall device, developed by ADI, that is used to communicate with submerged divers.

The CH-47 Chinook helicopters are also playing an important role in the gulf. Numerous Australian companies provided rapid and invaluable assistance in their preparation. Helitech of Brisbane and Craig Ballistics Industries on the Gold Coast developed and manufactured ballistic protectionâin layman's terms, bullet-proofingâfor the Chinooks. Hunter Aerospace in Townsville fitted and integrated key modifications to the Chinooks to ensure that they were fully adapted for operations in the Middle East. Tasman Engineering in Brisbane rapidly manufactured stands to allow the Chinooks to be deployed inside strategic lift aircraft. Australia's FA-18s, which are playing a crucial role in highly targeted bombing raids in Iraq, were originally assembled in Australia, and upgrades to them have been undertaken in Australia by Boeing.

Finally, I am sure that senators appreciate the massive logistics and supply effort involved in a campaign the size of the current action. Mincom, an Australian information technology company based in Brisbane, is recognised internationally as a world leader in this area, as well as in the area of mining software. Sixty per cent of Mincom's production is exported. In the current conflict, Mincom is providing the main transactional system for defence supply through its standard defence supply system, which is electronically taking care of our Defence Force supply needs. The vast majority of Australians hope and pray that the current military action is both swift and successful. Our thoughts are with our defence men and women who are in the gulf, and their families back in Australia. There is no doubt that their ultimate success will be, to a not insignificant extent, due to Australia's innovative and highly advanced defence technology industries.

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Hill, the Minister for Defence and the Minister representing the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs. In light of reports that the port of Umm Qasr is now in Anglo-American hands, is the minister aware that aid agencies are still unable to begin the delivery of food and other supplies until there is an environment free of combat operations and a reasonable expectation of security? Is this the reason that seven truckloads of food supplies from the Kuwaiti government which have reached Umm Qasr cannot be delivered immediately but have been handed over to the US troops now in control there? In light of the refusal of some agencies to send aid via the militaryâas this could make civilians targets and be seen as taking sidesâwhat is Australia, as a member of the coalition, doing to ensure that needed aid can be delivered safely and quickly to areas now cited as under coalition control?

âI have been indicating for the last few days a number of things that Australia is doing. One of the key things that our Defence Force has been doing has been to ensure that the waterway that leads to the port is clear of mines, to enable humanitarian aid to enter through the port. That is expected to be completed, hopefully, within the next few hours. The latest advice I have is that HMS Sir Galahad, the British support vessel, is likely to arrive in that port later this evening. That will be the first of a succession of ships delivering humanitarian assistance to the Iraqi people. Over the weekend, we are hopeful that the two ships carrying Australian wheat purchased by the Australian people for the Iraqi people will also be able to berth.
âIt is about the distribution of what is there.

âThe distribution in a war environment is not easy; nobody suggests that it is. But it is the wish not only of the coalition forces but of all the major humanitarian organisations that are on-site to see that it is distributed as effectively and efficiently as possible. I can go on and talk about other assistance, and the improvements in Basra in relation to humanitarian issues and the like, but we do not understate the difficulties of delivering this aid into such an unstable environment. We are doing our best to ensure that it can occur as quickly as possible.

âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. I will give the minister an opportunity to speak further on Basra. Is the minister aware of reports that people inside the city of Basra remain in dire straits, with water and power supplies not yet restored, although the main water station is now under the control of British and American forces? Is the minister aware that the International Committee of the Red Cross, the ICRC, has said that, although its engineers had partially restored water supplies from the main pumping station that was damaged by the fighting, more work needs be done to ensure clean water for all? What is Australia doing to actively persuade our coalition partners to provide water to Basra residents before a real public health emergency arises and people start to die of disease?

âMy advice is that, whilst the situation in Basra remains extremely difficult, conditions do seem to be improving. Iraqi water engineers and staff of the ICRC have partially restarted Basra's main water pumping facility. The ICRC estimates that 50 per cent of the city's approximately 1.5 million inhabitants now have access to drinking water. The coalition forces have started to repair the water treatment plant near Basra. The pipeline, which provides 2.4 million litres of water per day to Umm Qasr, will be operational by 30 March. I do not seek to understate the challenges, but I think that an objective assessment would be that progress is being made despite the difficulties.
âMy question is to the Minister for Defence. Have there been any confirmed reports so far of Iraq using weapons of mass destruction or of allied forces finding any weapons of mass destruction?

âI have heard no suggestion of weapons of mass destruction being used as yet, but it is still the obvious belief of the coalition forces that Saddam Hussein has such weapons and will use them as he believes appropriate to his military plans. In that light, it was interesting to note that when coalition forces entered an-Nasiriyah they found a hospital that had been used as a paramilitary headquarters staging and storage area. Interestingly, within the hospital were contained some 200 weapons, Iraqi military uniforms and a tank. That is of interest, but I want to particularly point out that in addition there were found within the hospital 3,000 chemical protective suits and nerve agent antidote injectors. That is further evidence, if Senator Bartlett needs itâmost of the world already accepts itâthat Saddam Hussein not only has the weapons of which Senator Bartlett speaks but has used them in the past and will be prepared to use them again.

âMr President, I ask a supplementary question in relation to the use of weaponry in Iraq. Could the Minister for Defence inform the Senate, based on the best information he has, of the number of deaths so far as a result of this warâthe number of deaths of coalition forces, Iraqi combatants, Iraqi civilians and civilians of other nations, including media?

âAs I have been asked for the best estimates of that number, I would need to seek further advice. I know the figures stated in the media in relation to civilians but I do not know whether those figures are accepted by the coalition force commanders. In relation to the deaths of Iraqi military personnel, they have been extensive. In relation to coalition personnel, I think the figure is around 30, but I would like to check that. We would wish to see no deaths of coalition personnel doing such an important task as ridding Saddam Hussein of weapons of mass destruction. But, in terms of past conflicts, that would be a very small number of casualties over a period of nearly seven days of a conflict involving half a million forces. (Time expired)

âMy question is to Senator Hill, the Minister for Defence. Is the minister aware that the United States has not ratified either of the additional protocols to the Geneva convention which impose additional obligations on parties to assist civilian victims of war, and that Australia has ratified both of them? How exactly is Australia complying with article 54 of protocol 1 of the Geneva convention, which prohibits state parties from attacking infrastructure, water installations, electricity and other civilian infrastructure, given that as a result of coalition attacks there is now no power or water being provided for the one million people living in Basra?

âI have answered that question before as well. Australia is a party to the protocols and accepts its obligations under protocol 1 in relation to civilian assets. The legal restraints that Australia has accepted have been incorporated within the rules of engagement under which our forces operate and the targeting directive of the Chief of the Defence Force.

âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware that, arising from these protocols, Australia has many legal obligations as an occupying power that the United States does not have, including the obligation to ensure that civilians have clothing, bedding, shelter and all other matters essential to a civilian's survival? What is the Australian government doing to meet its legal responsibilities to give humanitarian NGOs access to, and facilities in, all areas of Iraq in desperate humanitarian need?

âI am aware of the content of both protocols; I reread them in recent times when I had to finalise the rules of engagement and the policy relating to our targeting directive. I think the honourable senator is missing the obvious, however, which is that civilian casualties have been extraordinarily low as a result of the massive effort simply to avoid civilians. In contrast with past conflicts, the extent to which civilian casualties have been avoided has been a remarkable and outstanding achievement. In relation to supporting NGOs, as the countryâparticularly in the southâstabilises and can be opened up to NGOs, we would obviously wish to assist them in doing their task. We see them as being an important part of the solution.

âMy question is to Senator Patterson, the Minister for Health and Ageing. Given the large number of GP vacancies across Australiaâthere are some 1,200 in Queensland aloneâgiven that there are over 2,000 overseas trained doctors currently working to fill other vacancies, given the government's recent announcement that overseas students will be allowed to stay in Australia to fill vacancies in internships in our public hospitals and given that currently about one-quarter of our GPs are over 55, does the minister agree that the AMWAC figures that say Australia has more than enough doctors are quite wrong, if not dangerous? Does the minister agree that we must urgently find at least another 300 training places in our medical schools each year?

âI have said a number of times in this chamber that the issue of the work force, especially the work force in the area of health, is quite a difficult issue to measure. One of the reasons is that, particularly with doctorsâalthough with other health professionals as wellâthere is a long period spent in training initially and in the postgraduate years. Senator Lees would be aware that when I addressed the issue of the number of doctors I indicated that you cannot create a doctor overnight.

answer.para: When AMWAC indicated to me in a briefing that in the middle of this year they would be producing their next review of the medical work force, there was an indication that they were likely to indicate the need for more general practitioners. One of the things I was able to do immediately was to address, with Mr Ruddock, the issue of the students who are currently studying here from overseas and paying full fee. I have always indicated that that should not be a policy solution. I have been able to use it because of the suggestion that AMWAC may indicate that we require more doctors. I advise Senator Lees that I am cognisant of it, I am aware of it. I think I indicated that in the press release. I have immediately done as much as I can outside the budgetary process. I am aware of the issue and I am aware that AMWAC have indicated that they will be outlining in the middle of the year that we have a problem with the number of places in medical schools.

talk.start.para: âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for her answer. Given that it is going to take six or more years to train new doctors, would the minister consider expanding the practice nurse program that is beginning to work so successfully in rural areas into our cities so that city GPs would be able to enjoy the support services of a nurse at least on a one nurse for every two doctors basis, if not one for one as is done in many overseas countries?

âUnlike Senator Lees, the Democrats, the Labor Party and the Greens, I have responsibility as a member of the cabinet and a member of this government to ensure that we have a budget which is not taking money from the next generation for ourselves, as was happening when we came into government. In their last year of government the Labor Party spent $10 billion that belonged to the next generation. We have significantlyâ
âWhat is she talking about?
âWhat I am talking about is that Senator Leesâ

âMr President, I raise a point of order. This is not about expenditure. In fact, nurses are cheaper than doctors, if we want to get down to the absolute base level of it. This is about policy issues. Is the minister or is the minister not going to look at moving what is now a rural support system into our metropolitan cities where there are just as many shortages of GPs?
âI do not think that was a point of order. It was more likely trying to explain the supplementary question. I ask the minister to return to that question.

âBring back former Senator Walsh! It is not about expenditure! I do not know how you think you are going to get the nurses by not paying them. They will just come in and work for free! It is about expenditure. I am saying that I have to work within a budgetary process and I have to be sure that we do not spend more than we get in revenue. I am aware of some of the issues. I am not going to pre-empt what may or may not happen. We have a budgetary process, unlike Senator Lees, who thinks she can create nurses with no money. (Time expired).

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Defence Force: Support for Families

talk.start.para: âMy question is to Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Is the minister aware that there has been a dramatic 19 per cent increase in demand for Lifeline counselling and support services in the Army city of Townsville? Can the minister also confirm that this service, which receives no Commonwealth funding, is taking many calls from Army families who are reportedly uneasy, concerned, fearful, confused and angry? In the light of this information from Lifeline Townsville, does the minister consider that Defence Community Organisation support services in Townsville are adequately resourced to properly support defence families in North Queensland? What action will the minister now take to ensure all Townsville residents, including Army families, have access to adequate support at this difficult time?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI thank the senator for her question. It is pleasing to see a senator concerned about the families of service people who are in Iraq. I welcome the question.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI do not know whether they want the answer. Senator, no, I am not aware of the allegation you make. I am not saying it is not true; I am simply saying that I am not aware of it. I do not have reason to believe that it is not true. It would not surprise me if families of service personnel are seeking advice and counselling from a variety of sources. The prospect of losing one's son or daughter or sister or brother, as I have said, at any time would be difficult, let alone the prospect of losing them in military operations far away from Australia. Everyone in this place and certainly everyone in the broader Australian community understandâor I hope they doâthe pressure which families left behind are operating under on a day-to-day basis, especially when they cannot always get information about what their loved ones are doing.

answer.para: It would not surprise me if a number of counselling services have an increase in demand fuelled by service personnel contacting them. What I do not know with respect to this particular geographical region is the degree to which those service personnel are fully aware of the services I outlined either last week or early this week that are offered to families. I will make inquiries with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to see what publicity has been given in that area to those services to make sure that the service families are aware of the counselling, for example, that is available to them without going to Lifeline. There is nothing wrong with going to Lifeline; I think Lifeline offers a tremendous service. But there are other services provided by the Commonwealth that are equally available. That seems to be the most appropriate way of proceeding with the remarks that you make. The Commonwealth, I presume, funds a number of counselling services. I am not aware whether it funds Lifeline. But I take the key point of your question to be that there are service families of those in Iraq left behind who are concerned. That is agreed. You are concerned about whether they are aware of all the services available to them. I will take the matter up with the Minister for Veterans' Affairs.

talk.start.para: âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm an answer given in the House of Representatives by her colleague the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs yesterday that no additional funding has been made available to counselling services but that these services are free to apply for additional funding? Further, can the minister outline the process by which the department will make funding available in time to benefit counselling and support services, which are currently experiencing heightened demand?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: âI have not seen the answer apparently given by Minister Anthony yesterday in the chamber, but I have no reason to dispute your account of it. I will take up with him the process by which he expects people would apply. I do not know, for example, whether the question related simply to an increase in demand now as a consequence of service families or whether your supplementary question goes to the broader question of counselling services across the board to all Australians and the level of funding that they have. I will have a look at the question that was asked of Minister Anthony and his answer, have another look at yours and come back to you if there is anything I can add. Otherwise, I will ask Minister Anthony to forward to you the information that you seek.

âMy question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Will the minister outline to the Senate what steps the government is taking in relation to maritime and aviation security?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âThe Australian government has always been committed to a safe system of transport. Specifically, our security measures have been upgraded since September 11 and the Bali outrageâ and Senator Heffernan will know that. A couple of days ago, I advised honourable senators of the security arrangements in place at major airports since November last year. I thank Senator Heffernan for raising this question again. It allows me to focus on the maritime areas, and I know Senator Heffernan, being a regional senator, will also be interested in how increased security measures will impact upon regional airports. I am advised that no intelligence has been received requiring the raising of the overall threat level in Australia. Should any information become available to the government requiring a change to the threat levels, the public will be advised and appropriate additional security measures will be put in place.

answer.para: In the maritime area, we supported the December 2002 International Maritime Organisation's action to strengthen international maritime security arrangements, including the new IMO International Ship and Port Security Code, and we are moving to implement the new arrangements as a priority. The Department of Transport and Regional Services has taken the lead role on progressing the requirements of the IMO's ship and port facility security code to ensure that our maritime sector is well prepared for, and protected from, terrorist threats. This code will apply to approximately 300 facilities at about 70 ports in Australia and also to Australian flag ships involved in international trade as defined by the code. I am confident that Australia will be compliant with that code by the target date of 1 July 2004, if not before.

At the major ports in Australia we have a range of preventative security measures in place, such as access control, identity passes, closed-circuit TV, passenger and baggage screening for international cruise ships, and increased security patrols. Physical security measures at Australian ports are the responsibility of port owners. The majority of Australian ports, as honourable senators will know, are owned by state and territory governments, and many of them have been corporatised. There has been considerable liaison, consultation and cooperation between the states, the Commonwealth and the maritime industry over the last 14 months, and I anticipate that this will continue. The Australian Customs Service conducts immigration checks of incoming crews, screens containers for illicit drugs and guns, and also checks on quarantine matters and anything else that might be a threat to Australia's national security. In the regional aviation area, the current security measures that apply to regional airports are based on the best advice that we get from our security advisers, and they are constantly reviewed.

talk.start.para: âWhat about Devonport and Burnie?

âIt is not true to say, as many do, like Senator Sherry, that regional and smaller airports have been left out. Passenger screening does take place at 29 airports across Australia, and many of these are regional ports that receive jet services. (Time expired)

âMy question is to Senator Ian Macdonald, representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Is the minister aware of a report in the Fraser Coast Chronicle on 13 March 2003 in which the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Mr Truss, described the United States as `cheats' in relation to the delivery of developmental aid? Does the minister support Minister Truss's view in this regard? Is the minister aware that the United States has announced delivery of 600,000 tonnes of wheat aid for Iraqâthe first US wheat to enter Iraq for many years? Can the minister advise the Senate what implications this wheat aid has for Australian farmers in the context of our longstanding wheat exports to that country? Does this move by the US into a traditional Australian market add weight to Minister Truss's publicised view of the US as cheats?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âI am advised by Mr Truss that he did not call the United States cheats. I have seen the article in the paper, but you should know, Senator Moore, perhaps better than I, that you should rarely believe everything you read in the newspapers. Mr Truss denies making that comment.

answer.para: The senator asked whether I was aware that the United States was getting some wheat ready to send to Iraq. I expect that the United States might be looking at that as part of its aid programâthat is a matter for the United States government. What involves the Australian government is what happens to our wheat shipments. As the senator will know, and as I mentioned a couple of days ago, the Australian government has provided for humanitarian aid to Iraq in a very substantial amountâ100,000 cubic tonnes for the Iraqi people. Obviously enough, that wheat is sourced from Australia.

We expect that the Australian trade in wheat to the Middle East will continue as before. Perhaps trade will grow when the Middle East is safe, secure and peaceful again. We would anticipate that, with the fall of this regime in Iraq, there will be greater opportunities for trade between Australia and the Middle East in wheat and in many other agricultural products. Senator Hill mentioned earlier our expertise in dryland farming. We have identified experts we will be sending to help in Iraq as soon as is possible. We look forward to continuing good relationships with the Iraqi people. We want to continue to expand our trade with the Middle East generally and we expect that, when this regime in Iraq is finished, there will be much greater opportunities for Australia.

talk.start.para: âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like the minister to confirm whether the 100,000 tonnes of wheat to which he referred in his responseâthat we are now providing as food aid, as a humanitarian contribution, to Iraqâ had been contracted to the oil for food program prior to the suspension of that program at the beginning of the hostilities. How much is it expected to cost the government to provide 100,000 tonnes of wheat? Can the minister further advise whether this will be paid for out of the government's existing aid budget or whether it will be paid for with additional funding made available through the program?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation

talk.start.para: âIt is a very good questionâI agree with that. The wheat was in the Iraq waters as part of that arrangement and it will continue to go to Iraq as soon as it can possibly be safely put into the area. On your questions relating to the cost, I am afraid I do not have that information. I will refer that to the responsible minister, who I think is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, who deals with aid matters. As you know, I do not represent the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, but I will try to get that information and get an answer to you as soon as possible.

âMy question is to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. The minister would be aware of a report in the Herald Sun by Terry McCrann which criticises the government's approach on the removal of foreign ownership controls for media in this country. Given the minister's approach when in oppositionâthat is, that the Treasurer should not be the final arbiterâcan the minister inform the Senate what has changed his views since then?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI am not sure I would regard Mr McCrann as a model of consistency that should guide your consideration of these issues, butâ

answer.para: Opposition senators interjectingâ

talk.start.para: âI will put it a more charitable way: no-one is infallible in this business. I presume Senator Murphy is referring to the Senate inquiry into Fairfax. As I recall, the stakes got quite high at one stage because the Labor Party refused to make a public servant available and Senator Kernot refused to join us in having him put in jail or at least incarcerated in this building. I think we concluded at that time that it would have been appropriate for the Treasurer, or at least the FIRB, in making a decision as to whether a takeover was in the national interest, to provide reasons. The government of the day of course rejected that proposal and it has not since been resurrected, to my knowledge.

answer.para: In many ways, judgments on these issues depend on particular circumstances. If the Treasurer of the day is sufficiently forthcoming and the reasons are understood then people do not question the quality of the decision. If you take the Woodside decision, I think most people understood the basis on which that decision was arrived. If, however, you have someone like Mr Keatingâwho used to play politics with media issues for a living and introduced cross-media, with malice; we all know why Keating introduced the cross-media rule; it has been documented exhaustivelyâputting political considerations ahead of sensible policy issues, it is understandable that an opposition of the dayâand we are talking about 1994, I supposeâwould have felt that it was important that that Treasurer gave reasons. If you see it in that context, you will find that, since we have been in government, on the very few occasions when decisions in relation to foreign investment needed to be made and announced by the Treasurer, the circumstances that justified that decision have been well and truly understood and appreciated by the Australian community. Therefore, it has not been necessary to pursue that request to provide reasons. But it certainly was in those days.

talk.start.para: âMr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given the minister's response, I ask him: will you ensure that the legislation, when drafted, will provide for reasons to be given so as to avoid the political opportunism that you alleged back in 1993-94? Will you ensure that those reasons are actually laid out within the legislation so as to avoid the circumstances that you were so concerned about back in 1993-94?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: âI think Senator Murphy is talking in terms of the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act and the requirements that follow in that regard. Certainly I am not contemplating changes to that act. The starting point has to be whether, in the current environment, there is any basis for concern that decisions made by the government and announced by the Treasurer are inadequate or not sufficiently appreciated as to warrant further answers being given. Of course, there are plenty of forums in which these matters can be explored and it is perfectly open to Senator Murphy and many others to seek to pursue the climate in which those decisions are taken, but I do not think I have heard it raised in the last seven years as a matter that has required attention. Even the Labor Party has not raised it in the context of the current consideration of foreign ownership, and they would be the ones in favour of repealing that but not the cross-media rule. (Time expired)

âMy question is to Senator Ellison, the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs. Can the minister confirm that since 10 February 2003âthe same day that Prime Minister Howard met with President Bush to discuss the impending war in Iraqâthe Howard government has returned six Iraqi asylum seekers, having given them $700 each? Can the minister advise where these six Iraqis were returned to and confirm whether or not the six Iraqis are currently safe and protected? How many more Iraqi people is the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs currently seeking to return?

âI am aware that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Mr Ruddock, answered a similar question in the other place a short while ago. He advised that he was aware of six Iraqis being returned to Syria at their request and that they were currently in New Zealand. He mentioned another 39 who are still in detention and a remaining numberâin the order of 47, if I am correctâwho have been refused refugee status. It certainly is the case that there are fewer than 30 protection visa applications from Iraqis awaiting a DIMIA decision, with a further 3,700 protection visa applications lodged by Iraqis who already hold TPVs. Of this latter group, some 1,930 would reach the 30-month point of their TPVs by mid-2003. This is the point at which decision making on the further application would ideally commence.

answer.para: The processing of applications made by Iraqi asylum seekers is continuing wherever reliable decisions can be made. Of course there have to be inquiries made in relation to Iraq, and the current situation there is making things more difficult. Decisions on these cases will need to await comprehensive updated country information, which is being sought by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs as they continue to monitor closely the situation in Iraq.
